Award.AwardTitle: RDE-RAD: EAST Alliance for Students with Disabilities in STEM- Phase 2

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The EAST Alliance for Students with Disabilities in STEM ? Phase 2 project ??seeks to build upon prior accomplishments [EAST award, HRD-0333316] and, through a focused approach with regional partners, create a comprehensive ?Pipeline of supports,? which will serve as a model for institutes of higher education nationally? that are advancing high school, undergraduate, and graduate students with disabilities in STEM. The primary institution is the University of Southern Maine, partnering with three associate degree granting institutions (Southern Maine Community College, Central Maine Community College, Landmark College), and four high schools (Portland?s Deering, Casco Bay and Portland high schools, and Bonny Eagle high school which serves the communities of Buxton, Hollis, Standish and Limington).

The two primary goals of the project are : Increasing the number of students with disabilities that enroll in STEM majors, specifically natural, biological, chemical, and physical sciences, technology, engineering and mathematics, at the primary and partner institutions of post-secondary education, and Increasing the number of undergraduate and graduate students who successfully complete associate degrees, baccalaureate degrees and graduate degrees in STEM disciplines and enter the STEM workforce.

The refined ?steps for success? include two primary foci: Targeted STEM learning experiences for high school students with disabilities, and providing STEM academic support and research experiences for undergraduate students with disabilities. High school interventions will include field-based science research institutes for high school juniors and seniors, college credit coursework in math for high school seniors, and professional educational development for high school math, science and special education teachers.
College level interventions will include a learning community for freshman and transfer students, a freshman course in academic self-management, a research course for sophomores and juniors, undergraduate research fellowships in labs, the use of a ?student support team? integrating student support from project and university staff, and a series of faculty educational trainings on how to implement ?universal design for education? principles to facilitate student success.

The project will be evaluated by a team from the Education Development Center, led by Dr. Babette Moeller, using a mixed method approach to conduct both formative and summative evaluations. Dissemination will focus on institutions in the Southern Maine region as well as sharing the model with a national post-secondary audience.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
EAST-2: A Pipeline of Supports to Increase Graduation Rates for Undergraduate Students with Disabilities in STEM

 

While people with disabilities represent about 16 percent of the population aged 25-64, they represent only five percent of the STEM workforce, and are recognized as an underrepresented group in this field. Research suggests that attrition of people with disabilities from STEM occurs throughout postsecondary education. To increase the number of students with disabilities who successfully complete degrees in STEM and increase the number of students with disabilities who enter the STEM workforce, the University of Southern Maine (USM), with funding from NSF, has established the Eastern Alliance 2 for Students with Disabilities in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (EAST-2). Recognizing that career development is influenced by multiple personal, experiential, and contextual factors, EAST-2 has provided a pipeline of multi-faceted evidence-based supports and services for high school and college students with disabilities to help them successfully negotiate critical transitions. The EAST-2 pipeline combines STEM institutes and transition workshops for high school students with learning community seminars, undergraduate STEM research experiences, internships, mentoring, and tutoring for college students. EAST-2 also contributed to the development of capacity within high school and university STEM faculty to fully support students with disabilities through professional development in Universal Design for Learning (UDL).

 

Data gathered about the academic performance and graduation rates of participating students suggest that EAST-2 has been successful in increasing the number of students with disabilities who enroll, are being retained in, and graduate from STEM programs at USM. Between 2008 and 2013, 116 USM students participated in EAST-2. By Spring 2014, more than a third of the students (n=45; 39%) have graduated, and 40 (34%) of the EAST-2 participants are on track for graduation. Of those students who graduated, 19 (42%) are enrolled in graduate STEM programs, and 22(49%) are employed in a STEM field. The 4-year college persistence rate of EAST-2 students is 1.4 times as high, and their college graduation are more than double and graduate school enrollment rates are more than triple than those reported by NCES for the national population of students with disabilities. The overall improvement in retention, graduation, and graduate school enrollment rates that we have observed for EAST-2 participants mirrors trends that have occurred at USM at an institutional level. Between 2008 and 2013, STEM enrollment for students receiving disability services tripled, and their graduation rate increase more than ten-fold. By contrast, for the general student population enrollment in STEM programs increased by 8%, and graduation rates increased by 9% only.

 

Our data suggests that participation in EAST-2 contributed to these outcomes. Students who participated in a larger number and variety of types of EAST-2 activities over multiple years were more likely to have graduated or to persist towards graduation than students who participated in only one activity or for a shorter period of time. Interviews and surveys conducted with EAST-2 participants revealed that the pipeline of services impacted them in multiple ways. Science institutes and transition sessions for high school students contributed to students’ interest in pursing STEM, contributed to students’ knowledge and skills in STEM, and their understanding of and confidence with the college application process. Learning community seminars for college students contributed to students’ awareness of resources and supports available to them at USM, and their study and self-advocacy skills. POR.POR_COPY_TXT: EAST-2: A Pipeline of Supports to Increase Graduation Rates for Undergraduate Students with Disabilities in STEM While people with disabilities represent about 16 percent of the population aged 25-64, they represent only five percent of the STEM workforce, and are recognized as an underrepresented group in this field. Research suggests that attrition of people with disabilities from STEM occurs throughout postsecondary education. To increase the number of students with disabilities who successfully complete degrees in STEM and increase the number of students with disabilities who enter the STEM workforce, the University of Southern Maine (USM), with funding from NSF, has established the Eastern Alliance 2 for Students with Disabilities in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (EAST-2). Recognizing that career development is influenced by multiple personal, experiential, and contextual factors, EAST-2 has provided a pipeline of multi-faceted evidence-based supports and services for high school and college students with disabilities to help them successfully negotiate critical transitions. The EAST-2 pipeline combines STEM institutes and transition workshops for high school students with learning community seminars, undergraduate STEM research experiences, internships, mentoring, and tutoring for college students. EAST-2 also contributed to the development of capacity within high school and university STEM faculty to fully support students with disabilities through professional development in Universal Design for Learning (UDL). Data gathered about the academic performance and graduation rates of participating students suggest that EAST-2 has been successful in increasing the number of students with disabilities who enroll, are being retained in, and graduate from STEM programs at USM. Between 2008 and 2013, 116 USM students participated in EAST-2. By Spring 2014, more than a third of the students (n=45; 39%) have graduated, and 40 (34%) of the EAST-2 participants are on track for graduation. Of those students who graduated, 19 (42%) are enrolled in graduate STEM programs, and 22(49%) are employed in a STEM field. The 4-year college persistence rate of EAST-2 students is 1.4 times as high, and their college graduation are more than double and graduate school enrollment rates are more than triple than those reported by NCES for the national population of students with disabilities. The overall improvement in retention, graduation, and graduate school enrollment rates that we have observed for EAST-2 participants mirrors trends that have occurred at USM at an institutional level. Between 2008 and 2013, STEM enrollment for students receiving disability services tripled, and their graduation rate increase more than ten-fold. By contrast, for the general student population enrollment in STEM programs increased by 8%, and graduation rates increased by 9% only. Our data suggests that participation in EAST-2 contributed to these outcomes. Students who participated in a larger number and variety of types of EAST-2 activities over multiple years were more likely to have graduated or to persist towards graduation than students who participated in only one activity or for a shorter period of time. Interviews and surveys conducted with EAST-2 participants revealed that the pipeline of services impacted them in multiple ways. Science institutes and transition sessions for high school students contributed to studentsÆ interest in pursing STEM, contributed to studentsÆ knowledge and skills in STEM, and their understanding of and confidence with the college application process. Learning community seminars for college students contributed to studentsÆ awareness of resources and supports available to them at USM, and their study and self-advocacy skills.
